instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: fuse gets 10 volts on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> but blows on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S0_BKLT_FUSED</SIGNAL> when i solder fuse only on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> side it gets 10 volts on both ends. fuse will blow only when connected to pad leading to <RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR> there are no short to ground  on <RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR>,<RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> or <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR>. i get a shorth to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> but wouldnt board not be powering on? i do get an image on screen.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Check for short <TRANSISTOR>Q9701</TRANSISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C9715</CAPACITOR>-19 caps.
Does the fuse blow without LCD panel connected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: There is a short to GND on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>. Check with and without LCD to see if short is in LCD or not.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: replaced the fuse and disconnected lcd. as soon as i gave it power the trace on pin 1 of j9000 blew and took the pin with it..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
You didnt have to give it power... Just connecting or disconnecting the LCD and checking for a short while the board was powered off would've been enough. 

Anyways this means it's not inside of the LCD. Already tried to replace the display connector with a new one? I often find that one to be the culprit if I can't find anything ugly directly on the board itself

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: already ordered some connectors and will be installing tomorrow! it does seem to only be the connector nothing else is shorting guess ill find out tomorrow.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Usually when the connector is fucked the LCD cable will also be damaged. Inspect carefully before fucking up the connector again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: connector does look damaged! will order some of those as well. i got the connector installed and trace fixed i get 54volts on pin 1 of j9000 is that a normal voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: 54V means the backlight line has an open and is not connected to the LCD. So bad connector/bad cable or bad LCD.
